post/step-3-build.html.title: Step 3 – build
post/step-3-build.html.contents:
In step 1 and step 2 you installed and prepared the code to get posts from a WordPress blog. Now it’s time to build your new static site. Run the following command:

gulp clean-build
post/step-3-build.html.excerpt: Run and build your first static page.

post/step-2-add-you-wordpress-blog.html.title: Step 2 – add you WordPress blog
post/step-2-add-you-wordpress-blog.html.contents:
Inside the metalsmith.js file (in the folder gulp-tasks) you will find a variable at the top where you can add the address of your WordPress blog. Whether you use WordPress.org (own installation) or free / paid at WordPress.com. You should also add the hostname sitemapHostname used to generate the sitemap.xml.

Example:

const wordpressURL = 'staticsitegenerator.wordpress.com';
const sitemapHostname = 'https://www.example.com/';
post/step-2-add-you-wordpress-blog.html.excerpt: How to setup options to get content from your Wordpress.

post/step-1-clone-and-installation.html.title: Step 1 – clone and installation
post/step-1-clone-and-installation.html.contents:
I assume if you’re already familiar with tools like GIT and NPM. What you need to complete Step 1 is GIT and NPM installed on your computer.

Start by cloning the “Startup Package” from GitHub and install the required packages via npm.

git clone https://github.com/sjsd/static-site-generator-from-wordpress-rest-api
npm install

You are now done with Step 1.
post/step-1-clone-and-installation.html.excerpt: How to get the code and install the dependencies.

post/introduction.html.title: Introduction
post/introduction.html.contents:
Since you have found your way here, you already have knowledge about static page generation and WordPress. So I will not elaborate on the advantages or disadvantages of static page generation. There already exist a trillions generators out there made by genius people and that solves so many things. Plugin for publishing static JSON files from WordPress. There are even someone who earns money based on the same idea. We’ll ignore that they were first and focus on this project.

Common to many of them is that they either rely on the user to be able to create files and write Markdown. The cool kids these days use headless CMS. With that, there are also a number of advantages and disadvantages.

Ask yourself or your customers if they can anything about this. No? Do you know WordPress? Yes!

I based my code on a CMS that is very well known among many: WordPress. I know, I know … before you chop my head off: By using WordPress.com or somehow camouflage your own WordPress-installation you can / might get rid of many hackers. Most of us know how to use WordPress. Even your customer or grandma!

I believe using WordPress’ REST API is a great way to get content. My goal is to create a static page generator based on blog posts in WordPress. And maybe other stuff from WordPress. Who knows?!

I have three two goals for this project:

  1. Learning about Node.js, static page generation, WordPress REST API
  2. Free and open source
  3. *Get rich and famous

I will never get rich and famous by doing this. But I will get a lot’s of questions about why it doesn’t work on someones computer. I can’t wait!
post/introduction.html.excerpt: Introduction to the code and my thoughts about the project.
